title: 108_hr3961
content: The Act is titled the "United States Animal Identification Plan Implementation Act" and it establishes an Animal Identification Plan. The Animal Health Protection Act is amended to include a definition of the United States Animal Identification Plan, which encompasses various operational systems for identifying animals. The United States Animal Identification Plan includes operational systems for identifying animals, with implementation priorities for different livestock categories within specific timeframes after enactment. The United States Animal Identification Plan sets deadlines for livestock identification, with different timelines for various livestock categories after enactment. The Secretary can partner with states or third-party vendors to gather information for the plan while ensuring producer privacy. The Secretary may provide financial assistance of $50,000,000 to producers for complying with the animal identification plan. The plan does not fall under the Freedom of Information Act but is subject to the Privacy Act for information collected. The Secretary may allocate $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 to implement a subsection, with at least $25,000,000 designated for a specific purpose. If less than $50,000,000 is appropriated, up to $50,000,000 from the Commodity Credit Corporation funds can be used. However, the total amount used for this subsection cannot exceed $50,000,000. SEC. 3. RUMINANT FEED BAN. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, through the Commissioner of Food and Drugs, is responsible for monitoring and evaluating the implementation of regulations prohibiting animal proteins in ruminant feed. An annual report on the evaluation must be submitted to Congress. Additionally, an enforcement plan must be developed and implemented, including a hierarchy of enforcement actions and a timeframe for compliance. The FDA is responsible for enforcing regulations on animal proteins in ruminant feed, with an annual report to Congress and an enforcement plan that includes corrective actions and inspection timelines.
